Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 05:53AM - edited May 4, 2012 05:56AM by lago Newksmom there is much they don't know about cording but NO cording doesn't mean you have LE. It is thought that you have a higher risk by some but not others. That said I had cording in my right arm (4 nodes) but no cording in my left/cancer side (10 nodes). I have LE in my left arm but none in my right. So unless your PT said specifically you have LE, cording does not  mean an automatic diagnosis for LE. You can read more about it here: http://www.stepup-speakout.org/Cording_and_Axillary_Web_Syndrome.htm

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 07:03AM lago wrote: Barbie I had 10 nodes one one side and 4 sentinel on the other. During chemo my onc insisted I get BP on my arm since they nurses never did get a good reading on my leg. When they did it on my leg the machine made all kinds of noises because it was reading to high. I did not have high BP. What I did demand is they use the manual BP and not the machine. The machine tends to constrict much higher than the manual. After chemo was over I then made them take it in my leg. I find that my ankle is the best place. Still runs high but still in normal range. The issue with blood draws is, A. the have to constrict your arm and B. the actual stick could cause infection. With 2 nodes your risk is greatly reduced but it's still there. In my case since I do have LE in my 10 node are (much to my BSs surprise since I'm thin, etc.) I don't want to risk my other arm, which is my dominant arm. Right now I still have a port so I have them do blood draws from there. All IVs I've had done in my foot. I'm not sure what I'm going to do in the future because most places don't like to draw blood from the foot. There is a higher risk of infection from your foot than your arm.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 06:55PM lago wrote: Staff infections to spread really fast. Fever, nausea, warm around area, redness are all symptoms of regular staff infections. I also read this below source: www.allhealthsite.com/staph-in... Staph Mastitis symptoms Staph mastitis is an inflammation of breast tissues which occur mainly to breastfeeding mothers. The possible time period of its occurrence is within 6 weeks of child's birth. Symptoms of staph mastitis are: * Red painful lump in the breast with swelling. * Itchiness of breast skin and nipple * Nipple discharge * Fever * Lymph nodes close to armpit. IBC is very rare. Less that 5% of breast cancers are IBC.  It sounds like they diagnosed you properly. Staph can be difficult to treat so make sure you take those meds. Follow up with your doctor.

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2012 06:44AM lago wrote: KittyKitty I'm not an avocate of the FDA or Insurance. I have my issue with both. And I do get what you're saying. I will admit what really concerns me is "who" makes this decision. It should be a panel specialists (MDs) in the field at top rated hospitals picked randomly. But I still agree that some of the cuts make sense. I am not a fan of cutting mammos for under 50. I actually think that those with dense tissue need US/MRIs. I know my tumor in the posterior region would have been found before it reached over 6cm but my dense tissue hid it. I had to go in with a blood nipple before they found it. Might have saved me a breast or two, chemo, herceptin, reconstruction. Really the MRI would have been a lot cheaper if it caught this when it was just DCIS and I wouldn't have had chemo/Herceptin. So IMO early detection can actually saves money as well as lives.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2010 03:55AM lago wrote: Hi Jen: Sorry about the diagnosis. I must admit the beginning of this road to treatment was the scariest part. There is so much you don't know… and that's what's scary. Grade 3 describes the cancer cell. Grade 1 being a cell that looks more like a regular cell, grade 3 is just the oposite. All this grade, size, node status stuff is used to stage your cancer. Staging helps to decide what treatment you need. They won't be able to truly stage you till you remove (surgery) the cancer and they biopsy it. Seriously I went in to surgery with my breast surgeon pretty sure I was going to be a stage IIIA. Ends up I'm only a stage IIB. Bottom line is what my breast surgeon said to me when I first met with him. Breast cancer IS treatable.

Posts.Title: ASCO is trying to curb cancer costs again KittyKitty usafmom

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2012 05:41AM - edited Apr 7, 2012 05:42AM by lago I think you are missing the point. They are not saying don't give treatment to stage IV. They are talking about a point in time when treatment should be stopped because it is ineffective and will only ruin the quality of life. I know I have been told stories of people who have had loved ones killed by the "last ditch" try at chemo. I know my MIL died of lung cancer. They tried chemo but her end of life quality would have been terrible if they continued and she was dying. She was 86 years old and while my MIL would have wanted to live longer chemo would have only made her last days/months even worse.They all knew she was dying. The goal was to keep her as comfortable as possible. I do agree that there are a very few cases that beat the odds but it's so few. Our medical/insurance costs are so high that some people can't even get good treatment because they can't afford it. The medicare system here is so burdened that if something isn't done sick elderly won't be able to afford any cancer treatment bbecause medicare will only pay a small portion of it. Right now it looks like anyone who is younger than 55 will not be eligible for medicare till they are 67. (That would include me). Remember no one can tell you when your number is up but a good doctor can tell when it's time for hospice just like there is a time for scans. I do believe good doctors are already doing this. I know my onc doesn't  scan for low risk of mets in early breast cancer unless there is a symptom. She doesn't do tumor markers either because they are unreliable.She also prescribed Anastrozole instead of one of the non generic from the get go with me. Basically she is doing everything recommended in that article all ready. Most of us never see the "bill" till after treatment in the US. I think this is part of the issue too.  Coolbreeze I don't know what my post count has to do with this.You know most of the time I post support for others in my posts. As far as disingenuous, hardly. I've also had 2 grandmothers pass from cancer. One from colon cancer the other lymphoma both found at stage IV. Both were in their late 60's which IMO is pretty young. My grandmother who had colon cancer did chemo for a while. It extended her life for 4 months but event she chose to stop… the SE weren't worth a "maybe" a month or so.  I would think a doctor could see this.  I am not being disingenuous. I really hope, if I ever had to face this (knock on wood) that I know when it's time to stop. I understand the drain on the system. I don't want to drain the system so people (including children) can't get care because I might be getting expensive treatment that won't offer any value. Before my BMX I did have a "do not recesistate" etc form that I signed.  You are all entitled to your opinions. This is just mine. Reading "Welcome to the Monkey House" when I was in my 20's made a huge impression on me. Sorry for posting in the IV thread but this is an issue that effects everyone. The discussion includes scanning for early stage so that would be me.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 07:08AM lago wrote: amyK I am so sorry you are experiencing this.  I was on TCH (finished 3.5 weeks ago) so I don't know if this works the same. When I first started to get neuropathy my onc said we need to watch it. If it got worse she was going to lower my dosage. I just have a numb left heel, not too bad so my dosage was never lowered. I don't know what kind of meds you have been given to control the SE. Some things can't be controlled by meds. (I got that rare SE were all my finger nails and some of my toe nails lifted, are sore, ooze, smell as well as a few fell off. Very gross and uncomfortable but I'll live). Things like heart burn nausea, low white counts, thrush all have meds. For mouth sores I sucked on ice during infusion and it seemed to keep them at bay. Not much they can do for the stiffness although mucle aches can be managed with Aleve if they let you take that. Sometimes you really need to push your onc. All through chemo I kept gaining 4-5 lbs overnight then once I took the steriod the day before chemo it dropped off. Now that I'm off chemo the fluid kept coming on. My legs were so bad you couldn't see my ankles. Finally they put me on a low dose diuretic. I have lost 8.5lbs in 3 days! Yes you need to be a squeaky wheel sometimes to get them to realize the issue.  When you look good they sometimes don't realize. Yes we lost our hair but it looks like you (just like me) have hung on to your eyebrows and lashes. I hope you can make it through the last AC. I have A is really rough. I too wanted to give up after tx4 and especially tx5 but I manged to get through all 6 tx. All I can say is this better work .I don't want to do this again…one of my main motivators for finishing!

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2011 06:15AM lago wrote: Bevin Actually it isn't that unusual for a stage IV to start with the least aggressive treatment. Early stage they treat to cure and therefore big guns. Stage IV or mets they know they can't cure and hope for remission. Quality of life is important. They treat it like a disease similar diabetes. Use the treatment with the least amount of SE to control the disease. The problem with cancer is it can mutate so eventually she will be doing something else but some people are on the hormonals for years/decades before they need to try a different treatment. So yeah these anti-hormonal drugs are really some of the great guns to go into breast cancer battle with.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 04:20AM lago wrote: My right SNB my BS actually took out 4 because 4 lit up. It can happen. On the left side though he didn't do a SNB and took out level 1, 10 nodes total. If he found invasion he would have taken more. Why no SNB on the left? Because I had a very large (they thought 7cm going in but only 5.5cm) tumor that was very fast growing and grade III. Although both the physical exam and MRI didn't show any invasion the possibility of a micro invasion with a tumor like mine was something like 80%. My BS really thought that I would have a micro invasion. I think his entire office celebrated when I ended up with no node invasion. Yes I feel luck. I ended up being a stage IIB instead of a stage IIIA. Not only statistically better but my treatment was a little less aggressive.
Posts.Title: don't get the whole "nodes" protocol slcst12 otter

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2010 04:06PM lago wrote: First of all the need to know if its in the nodes to stage  your properly. Staging is so important when deciding on what treatment (and how much). Why remove? Well if there's cancer in them you want them to be removed before those cells move into your body somewhere else and/or grow larger tumors. It's the same reason why they removed your primary tumor. You get chemo just in case there are some cells that did get a way and are in other parts of the body that need to be killed. Finally chemo is still a crap shoot. Sometimes it doesn't work and sometimes it does. Most of the time it does or they wouldn't give it to us but of course we know there are times when it does not. If you know there is cancer then best to cut it out if you can… that goes for the nodes too. I always joked that my cancer center tends to treat on the aggressive side. If I could live without bones/liver/lungs/brain the might consider removing those too ;-)

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 05:36AM - edited Jan 23, 2011 05:37AM by lago I don't want to scare you but with all breast cancer there is a recurrance risk. Some risk higher than others of course. It does appear that with hormome positive that risk is always there where as the risk does seem to go down for hormone negative after 3 years. No treatment of course increases that chance. Here are some links on recurrance: http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1248209720080812  Note at the end of this article: "…The study found that women who had tumors known as estrogen receptor positive, in which the hormone estrogen is driving the tumor, had a higher risk of these late recurrences compared to women whose tumors were not this type. Women who had low-grade, or less aggressive, tumors, actually had a higher risk of late recurrence than women who had higher grade tumors, Brewster said. "That was certainly a finding that we were surprised to see…" http://www.gaeainitiative.eu/word_page/BC_Recurrence.htm http://www.lifeabc.org/risk_recurrence_more.html

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 02:17PM lago wrote: Ergirl I wasn't given a choice but given that I am HER2+ I got Herceptin too. Herceptin is know to have cardio toxicity and even worse with A so my onc prefers TCH (H being herceptin, C being carboplatin) to AC-TH. The taxotere induced alopecia they are finding is about 3%-6%. I found out about this after my 1st TX so it was too late to do anything but all my hair did come back. While the risk is low it is very real. Some oncs don't admit this is an issue yet. I have read that neuropathy can be worse with Taxol than Taxotere. I would also discuss this with your onc. I do have neuropathy in my left heel (numbness) that isn't too bad but it looks like it won't be going away. I'm 1.5 years post my final chemo. Yes you have choices but they all have sucky SE that may or may not happen.

Posts.Content: Nov 27, 2011 08:32AM lago wrote: Fufu you are not wrong but there is still a lot of information she doesn't have and won't have till she has surgery. The true size, if it's in her lymph nodes etc. Has it been tested for HER2 yet? If she is HER2+ this is a very aggressive tumor that needs to be treated with Herceptin to have significantly better outcomes. Problem is Herceptin is rarely given without chemo because it works better with chemo. Hopefully she will not be HER2+ . Typically they test everyone for HER2+ these days because Hercepin makes that much of a difference in prognosis for those of us who need it. It seems breast cancer tends to be more aggressive in younger patients. Even I was considered young (diagnosed at age 49) and as you can see had a very aggressive fast growing tumor.  Sounds like she is slowly coming to terms with her condition. Just don't overwhelm her but she does sound like she is listening. Remind her that the drug companies may make a lot of money on chemo but the insurance companies don't like to pay for it. It is kind of a check and balance in my mind. I know a lot of alternatives claim that the drug companies have a cure but make too much money on cancer drugs so they won't publish the info on alternative. They also claim that the doctors are getting kick backs from the drug companies. There is this big conspiracy theory that is just BS. If you are going to a good treatment center this is not the case. I don't know of one oncologist out there that wouldn't love to see a cure or a treatment without so many SE. BTW chemo is supposed to work best on fast growing cancers (ones that are grade 3, and/or HER2+, triple negative etc.) Hopefully this info will be presented to her.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2011 03:07PM lago wrote: Fufu I was scared of chemo too. When we think of chemo we think of what we see on TV… usually the character only has a week to live. Chemo isn't fun but no way near as bad as I thought. She should visit some of the treatment/chemo centers. Some are better than others. She might be surprised.  As far as holistic. The theory is to let the body heal itself. While I do believe out bodies do this most of the time, if you get cancer you body isn't doing it. So many of us here have had perfectly healthy life styles and "did nothing wrong" but still got cancer. I personally favor complimentary not alternative. This is because I feel there are many things that have to be in place in order to get cancer. You can't solved the problem with just one method in most cases especially the later the stage cases. While a stage 0 or I might be able to just do surgery and holistic and have very successful outcomes I have seen those successes go way down as the stage goes up. I would try to get you relative to talk with women that have gone through this. I would also talk in terms of complimentary. Explain that she can build her body back up after chemo with complimentary. BTW I have to add that I did the bilateral mastectomy, 10 nodes one side, 4 nodes other side, 6 rounds of chemo, a full year of Herceptin and now 5 years of Anstrozole (now that I'm in perminent chemo-pause) and I feel great. Almost done with my reconstruction too. Just have tattoos.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 09:24PM lago wrote: EnglishMajor as far as insurance your state has high risk pool insurance. So if you should get laid off and run out of Cobra this is an option… no wait period as long as you don't let your Cobra lapse. States with high risk insurance pools. Like most plans if you do not include maternity and don't smoke the premiums is much much lower. I assume both are a non issue for you. People here have given you really great advise. Only you know how you feel living with this disease. I would pin your onc down given the situation though. If you feel it's time for SSDI then go for it. But have you considered that you may live a long time? What happens if you go into remission for 20+ years. Will SSDI (plus supplemental work) be enough to live on in 10, 15, or 20+ years? As far as the Jack(_!_)es at work. You know they are everywhere. Don't let it get to you. We all forget that we can't expect people to behave like we would… although it would be nice if they did. Not everyone has our values. Mostly people at work care about themselves. To be honest even telling them you have metastatic breast cancer will get them to think about you only as long as it takes them to say "I'm sorry to hear that." When you leave the room the will forget about you in most cases. They're co-workers not friends. And remember at this job you know who the Jack(_!_)es are and how they operate. At the new job you will have to learn about this all over again. Hopefully there will be fewer.  IMO it never hurts to look. You should always be ready with an updated resume in these times. No one ever knows when or where the axe will fall. Also  you know just because someone offers you a job doesn't mean you have to take it. This might help you decide weather to stay, go or sign up for SSDI

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2010 11:50AM lago wrote: Just had my 2nd round of chemo Tuesday. Granted not the same cocktail (Taxotere, Carboplatin & Herceptin) as you but all these chemos have their own and similar SE. I was so scared too. So far I think the worst SE I experienced was from the Zyertec… I was such a space cadet and tired the 1st time from it but my body finally got used to it. Odd that the over the counter drug bothered me more. The chances of you getting all those symptoms is pretty slim. Most of them are manageable. No one should be nauseous on chemo these days. If the anti nausea drug the give you doesn't work then make sure they give you a different one. Last round my worst day was day 6 which would be today. I had terrible back pain. This time I took Aleve last night and this morning… I'm cleaning the house including vacuuming!  ----------------------------------------------------- The actual infusion should not be difficult. They infuse you slowly the first time to make sure you don't get a reaction.  I bring a book but I think next time I will also dig out my old gameboy and play some computer games. It's really uneventful. More of a time suck than anything else IMO. ------------------------------------------------------- Oh and I'm one of those who cut their hair short but didn't go bald yet. I'm pretty thin on top so I don't go out without a scarf. I think my husband is actually getting a kick out watching the transition. Maybe by the end of this week I'll have it shaved before I start to look like Gollum. I have to agree this isn't so bad so far. Granted everyone is different but I was expecting the worst. I hate nausea. Though for sure I would get it. Haven't taken any drugs for it except for the required Emend the day of and 2 days after.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2010 01:28PM lago wrote: Sorry your daughter had to join us. If she is really young there is a "Young Women with Breast Cancer" cancer section with many threads:  http://community.breastcancer.org/forum/27 `````````````````````````````````````` I'm 1/2 through my chemo: Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herecepin followed by Herceptin (1 year) with Arimidex and Zometa (I have ostiopenia). Chemo put me in chemopause. I'm 49 (almost 50) so my onc feels that I will not get my periods back. This is why I will be taking an aromatase inhibitor like Arimidex. Tamoxifen is usually taken by pre-menopausal women and some post. With triple positives there are SOME women that do not metabolize the drug well. If this is the case then the ovaries can be suppressed with drugs or removed allowing aromatase inhibitor as part of the therapy. Some suggest going the drug suppression first and if that is too much then remove the ovaries. The argument is once the ovaries are gone you can't go back but… it also might be an age issue. I ended up not having radiation but that's another topic. Usually with a lumpectomy and/or positive nodes,and  large tumors radiation is prescribed.  There are many other factors that require radiation too. SE from chemo. Well I'm doing rather well. I actually worked out for 70 minutes (35 elliptical & 35 treadmill/fast walk) the day after this last chemo. I took it easy just one day and that was more due to the SE of the Nuelasta shot than chemo. I have yet to get any of that tired/weak flu like symptoms. No nausua either. My SE: • Some back/neck/jaw pain but I'm pretty sure its from that shot •  I had heartburn the first treatment and Prilosec didn't work for me. I'm on prescription Protonix now and it works great. Note that "Prilosuc" never worked for me prior to chemo either so I wasn't surprised by this. •  I do have a little neuropathy but not bad. Mostly my left heel goes a little numb. It's worse in the morning but once I start walking on it it's much better. It almost goes away by next treatment. • Day 3 &4 I could have constipation but I start with the metamucil on night 2 and didn't have the problem this time. •  day 6 my tongue gets a little sore and spicy food irritates it so I don't eat spicy food. Goes away in about 3 days. • Day 6 My taste buds slightly change but not bad. My only issue is when I decide to cook on those days I can't truly taste what I'm cooking so  I need someone around to make sure I've added enough ingredients. ;) •  Day 8 nose bleeds. This is most likely from the Herceptin but does eventually stop •  Of course I have hair loss. Still some left on my head but very little. I probably should shave it. I lost my arm pit hair and I've only shaved my legs twice in 7 weeks. I also lost quite a bit of  hair "down under" Still have my eyebrows although I might have lost some lashes. ```````````````````````````````` Also note that my doctor does precribe lots of meds from the start including Emend, Zyrtec (take daily), corticosteroid, Nuelasta and Prilosec (daily).  Hope that helps a bit.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 12:27PM lago wrote: I packed a bunch of crap and left it in the car. Never needed anything except the clothes I came in with and a pillow for the ride home. I recommend wearing a loose button up shirt and pants that are easy to pull up. If you are doing diep many women recommend soft yoga pants/sweat pants that are easy to pull up. Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 03:47PM lago wrote: The oncotype test is very expensive. Insurance will only pay for it in most cases if you are early stage AND no nodes. I was early stage and no nodes but did  not get the test because I was HER2+. When you are HER2+ you automatically get chemo & Herceptin together in most cases. Your report needs to have you as early stage, clear nodes and HER2- in order to get the test paid for. They need the path report to figure that out.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2010 08:19AM lago wrote: There is risk with any surgery and that includes anesthesia but that's why they have an anesthesiologist right in the room watching you. They monitor your vitals to make sure you are OK. The risk is low or they wouldn't do this. I was nauseous but only when I moved around. I hear they can give you something for that if you know you're the type that does get nauseous. I didn't know because it was my first time under general anesthesia too. Don't drive yourself crazy. Anytime you go into surgery they always tell you you can die. It's CYA. If people died all the time they wouldn't be doing this. You're more likely to get into a car accident on your way there… and I'm sure that won't happen either.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 08:32PM lago wrote: Itching sounds like they are healing. You should follow the instructions you were given. You don't have stitches. The steri-strips hold the incision together. You need to give it time to heal. Steri strips should start to come off by themselves after the 2 weeks. If the incision opens you open yourself up to infections and maybe even more complications. If it's that uncomfortable call tomorrow.
Posts.Title: ? about steri-strips BioAdoptMom3 marticcrn

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2011 12:33PM - edited Jun 27, 2011 01:36PM by lago Whitty there is a lot of mis information out there that is very convincing. Don't get sucked in. You are at a very vulnerable time so it happens. I see you are HER2+ This is a very aggressive form of the disease. They don't do oncotype testing on HER2+ stage II cancers because you will be prescribed the drug Herceptin. Herceptin works better with chemo. Yes there is risk associated with chemo and radiation. I won't lie about that but the risk is low. You should write down all the question you now have after watching that movie and talk to your oncologist or the oncologists nurse practitioner about this.  I will also admit that there is a chance you don't need anymore treatment. Problem is there is know way of knowing except to do nothing and see if the cancer comes back to another part of your body. At that point it's much harder to treat and there is definitely no cure. Chemo isn't fun but you get through it. I finished in January. I've been told radiation isn't near as bad but radiation wasn't recommended for me so I really can't comment with first hand experience. I have to ask, Do you trust some people online you have never met and don't know their credentials over your doctors? Use the information you get online to question your doctors but don't assume it's the truth. For what it's worth I did chemo, now on the estrogen sucking drug and would do it again given what I know. HER2+ is nothing to mess around with! (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 05:45AM lago wrote: cbear I waited a total of 2 months between mammogram and surgery. I had an extremely large and fast growing (grade 3 & HER2+ which mean really fast and aggressive) tumor at 6.5cm. I too was worried about it going into my nodes. I too had to wait to get the MRI and the BRCA test. The MRI did not indicated any nodal involvement. but still had to wait 4 weeks before I was scheduled. My BS even thought I would at least have a micro invasion… but my nodes were all clear. Most breast cancer doesn't grow that fast. Many of us have had our tumor for 8-10 years before it will be spotted. In my case because it was so fast growing I only had it for 4 years. A few weeks really won't make the difference. which means you have time for a 2nd opinion. I recommend getting one. You can still go to this guy if you want even after the 2nd opinion. Women do it all the time.

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2012 04:51AM lago wrote: Edithesther I don't know how healthcare works in Great Britain but I would recommend you discuss this with your doctor. Here in the US many of us get MRIs before surgery per their BS request. In some states it's a law that you can have an MRI if you have very dense tissue. I too had very dense tissue and the mamo didn't pick it up till it was 6-6.5cm. MRI caught the LCIS in the other breast. Typically LCIS is not picked up by mammo or US.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 05:48AM lago wrote: cbear the reason I know is I got my full path report after my BMX and that's because I picked up at the office. I live close. I never got my path report after my biopsy. Was just told ER+/PR+ HER2+ IDC. I spoke with my BS over the phone about having to have the MX (tumor too large for lump) but that was just fine with me but not typical. I have a family member that is a physical at my center so things weren't always done in the typical way. I really didn't want to go in for another apointment… you will be doing plenty of that between tests and doctors. OMG it will be your social calendar for several months! The true pathology comes after surgery. Things can change from the biopsy. If you don't like the way you are being handled maybe it's time to get a 2nd opinion.
Posts.Title: What will a MRI show my doctor that they dont know already? cbear cbear

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2012 05:08AM lago wrote: cbear it's 40% chance it will come back if you only do surgery. At the very least you will be doing some kind of hormone therapy, radiation and maybe chemo BUT you won't know anything about your treatment till after surgery. They really need the final pathology from the lumpectomy to be sure of the paths accuracy. If you are node negative, HER2 negative and hormone positive there is a chance you might not need chemo. They will do an oncotype test unless they feel based on family history and/or young age that you really should do chemo. These are good discussions to have with your oncologist.
Posts.Title: What will a MRI show my doctor that they dont know already? cbear cbear

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2012 07:03AM - edited Nov 21, 2012 07:04AM by lago cbear I don't know a lot about it because although I was hormone positve and node negative I am HER2+ with a large tumor. That automatically means I get chemo. The oncotype test tells many things but one thing is can do is predict if chemo will be effective for you or if hormone therapy alone is enough. At times it comes up in the middle so then it's sort of a toss up what to do. This link gives you lots of info on the test: linky
Posts.Title: What will a MRI show my doctor that they dont know already? cbear cbear

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 08:47AM lago wrote: I'm not stage III (but only 1 node away from it). It gets better for most of us. You have to realize that  your risk of getting into a car accident is probably pretty high but you don't worry about it every time you get into a car. You put on your seat belt and drive safely. Same with breast cancer.  You do what you need to do to reduce risk: treatment, exercise, maintain a healthy weight, reduce alcohol consumption, etc. In order to be a survivor you need to enjoy life. None of us know when our final day is. There's always that bus we need to watch out for too.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 07:19PM - edited May 12, 2011 09:14AM by lago Someone PMed about this thread. I guess I'm now famous for gross nails. Great This happened to me on Taxotere. It is a SE but rare especially to get it as bad as I did. My nails started to hurt first then lifted. Blood (darkening) underneath several also occurred. Many of them oozed smelly stuff, some did bleed a little too. It was pretty disgusting. I did have to get one toenail removed. A few others fell off. For some reason I didn't loose any of my fingernails although every single one lifted. There was a point where I could only wear my big combat boot type shoes because all my other shoes put pressure on the toenails… making it difficult to walk. At some point my fingernails all hurt too. One time my thumb actually was throbbing. Even now some of my fingernail beds are still a little tender. I still don't use most of my nails to scrape labels off yet. They are much better now and growing out. Toenails still look like crap but much better. Tomorrow I'll try and take pictures and update this post. 1 more thing. Try to use them as little as possible. Every time you put pressure on them you stress the more. My podiatrist told me this. Be sure to tell your onc about this. I didn't think it was a big deal when it started. I told her about my toes and she wanted to see… she sent me to a podiatrist. I also saw a dermatologist for the fingers just to make sure they weren't infected. ---------------------- FInger pictures ---------------------- This is when it started. I do have clear nai polish on: linky 1    Black nail polish on. One finger became swollen but no infection. Note the date is Feb 12th but I had my last chemo on Jan 18th: linky 2    Most of the nail polish is off now. You can see some nails do have blood/dark underneath. Finger no longer swollen Feb 21st: linky 3 ------------------- Toe pictures ------------------- Clear nail polish on toes. Bit nail lifted with whitish stuff underneath. It was draining smelly stuff too.:  toe linky 1  This is the gross pictures. The black on the toe is not polish. That is underneath. The skin on my toes also dried out on chemo: toe linky 2 Any other questions feel free to ask. UPDATE PHOTOS from today: fingers   toes

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 06:13PM - edited Nov 3, 2012 06:14PM by lago MRI will give your surgeon a better idea of what's in there. It's better imaging than Mammo or US. When your tissues is dense it can reveal things that a mammo/US can't. Also conditions like LCIS many times doesn't show up on Mammo or US. My "good breast" had a small amount of LCIS. My BS then recommended a BMX. I did have very dense tissue. MRI is much more sensitive so sometimes it can indicate problems when there are not any. I had 4 suspicous areas on the left but only one was LCIS. Rest were cysts.
Posts.Title: What will a MRI show my doctor that they dont know already? cbear cbear

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2012 09:23PM lago wrote: cbear I strongly suggest you get a 2nd opinion. There is a slightly higher risk of local recurrence with lumpectomy but even if that should happen then you would get a mastectomy (mx). Survival is the same. If you do a bilateral MX (BMX) then your chances of getting a new breast cancer goes down significantly. They can't remove all the breast tissue but do get most of it. If you go for the lumpectomy you will be watched closely so they will catch it early if you were to get a new breast cancer. I too was told I am small but my tumor was very large so I had to have at least one breast removed. It is a very personal decision. Also remember if you remove both breasts you will lose sensation in both breasts. You might also want to discuss this with a radiation oncologist. S/He might be able to give you a better idea about what happens to your breast if you radiate it. Lots of women go the lumpectomy and have no regrets, and lots of us go with the bmx with no regrets as well. But no doctor can tell you for sure it will never come back. Granted if you are a stage I and especially if you have no lymph node invasion the chances are very small it will come back if treated. You will not now for sure till surgery what is really in there. Sometimes it's better than they thought. I know initially they told me my tumor was 7cm. Ends up more like 6/6.5cm but only 5.5cm was invasive. That's a lots smaller. BTW I was age 49 at diagnosis. I had no nodes. Just passed the 2 year mark in August. My gut tells me it's not coming back. One final note. If you decide to go with the lumpectomy do tell you BS (breast surgeon) that if he finds more than he thought and you need the MX to go ahead and sign the papers before hand. If you don't give him permission to do that and he does find more he'll have to close you up and schedule another surgery to do the MX. It happened to my neighbor. It's uncommon but best to be ready for everything.

Posts.Title: Dimple on Breast and Breast enlarged emma22 emma22

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2013 06:18AM lago wrote: emma please remember that 4 years prior to diagnosis I felt some soreness (when pressed) and my primary care said he didn't feel anything. I also had a mammo that saw changed that required a call back for US. I even saw a BS and they all said it was nothing. 4 years later in the same spot I had a 6.5cm tumor! So even if everyone still says it's nothing have a follow up in 6 months. Also ask your doctors if you have dense breast tissue, and how dense because in that case I would want an MRI. I didn't have lobular in that breast but lobular cancer is very hard to detect especially in dense tissue and if the tumor is closer to the chest wall. This is something you don't want to be wrong about. Catching it early is so important. You have 2 Signs. Let your doctors know about the increased size and dimple. Molly good luck and let us know how all turns out.
Posts.Title: Dimple on Breast and Breast enlarged emma22 emma22

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 09:30AM - edited Feb 24, 2013 09:30AM by lago Any changes in your breast is something to be concerned about. I wish I had known that because I would have insisted my issue was followed up. Go call your gynecologist and see if s/he can recommend a good breast surgeon for you to see. "I don't see or feel anything" is not a diagnosis for a dimple and a breast enlarging. It may not be cancer but why not find out what's causing this. Also if it were to be cancer the sooner you find out the better. My tumor was part non-invasive. It it had been found when the entire tumor was non-invasive I probably wouldn't have needed chemo. keep us posted You have 2 of the sign indicating it could be breast cancer according to the American Cancer Society (linky). By any chance are you young. The only sign I had was I noticed a small amount of blood coming from my nipple (size of a pin prick) in my sports bra. Go to a specialist. With your symptoms you must find out what's causing this. Are you in the USA? Near a major city with a teaching hosptial?

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2013 11:24PM lago wrote: I would go and see a breast surgeon especially if you have dense breast tissue. I had a scare 4 years prior to being diagnosed. Also had the US and Mammo. My tumor was in the posterior region so it was hard to see. Even when I did go in with a bloody nipple and got the diagnostic mammogram they said "suspicious but not typical of breast cancer." I switched to another place, saw a breast surgeon and he knew just looking at the mammo that this wasn't a good sign. Mammmos and US are only as good as the radiologist reading them. Don't wait. Get looked at someplace else. While this might not be cancer this is some reason why you are having dimpling and your breast is 25% larger. BTW my tumor was 6.5cm by the time I had that last mammo/US. I saw my former gyno just 5 weeks prior and she didn't feel anything. I had small breasts too. Not sure why it wasn't found at least a  year if not 2 years prior. It was in the same spot as that suspicious area 4 years prior.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 08:24AM lago wrote: They won't know the stage till they do the pathology after the surgery. They won't know about the lymph node involvement untill they do a sentinel node dissection or remove even more and dissect them. They can't even be sure of the size of the tumor till they remove it. Initially they said mine was 7cm but ended up only 5.5cm. Biopsy can only tell (but not always 100%) type (in her case Invasive infultrating carcinoma) tumor grade (1-3, this is different than stage), hormone status and HER2 status. The HER2 status takes longer because they must send it out to a specific lab. Usually it takes about 1 week after the biopsy to get all that info… and then at surgery they retest all those things. I had blood work, chest X-ray and MRI before my surgery. They really wanted to do the MRI to see what was going on in the other breast. Good thing they did in my case. Since my tumor was so large, agressive and HER2+ I had the CT & bone scans before but this isn't always typical. They usually do them after surgery. I saw an onologist 2 weeks after surgery for the first time. Some people have a team set up from the start. Some don't. It really didn't make a difference for me because I wasn't getting chemo before hand. If my tumor was bigger or they thought it has spread to other parts of my body then I would have done chemo first. Nothing wrong with your friend talking with an oncologist now either. If she is concerned the get a 2nd opinion.

I have brown and grey hair). I always had very shiny hair but it took months before my old shine came back. My hair seemed more like fur than hair. I one the other hand will be cremated with my hair colored when that time comes. For me it's more about reducing stuff I ingest and breathe on a daily basis. So much crap in and on food. No way at their age is that their natural color. Seriously they still don't really know what causes breast cancer BUT the most important thing you can do to reduce your chances of recurrence is exercise at least 30 minutes a day. 2nd most important is healthy weight.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 07:59AM - edited Jan 13, 2011 08:06AM by lago Barbe those are the most common. They also have a category called "Unclassified/normal breast-like." I think it's just interesting classification compared to basic staging. As far as "nearly 50% of those of us dxed with invasive bc go on to develop mets" We don't know what that statistic encompasses. They might be counting women since the 50's. We don't know how the women were treated either. That article also says my stage IIB prognosis is 65% survival of 5 years. According to my onc if I only had surgery it was 40% (10 years) but with chemo/herceptin/als its more like 84% (2% chance of dying from something else) or basically 14% chance it will come back in 10 years. Just 10 years ago those of us with early BC and HER2+ would have a 50% higher rate of mets than today because of Herceptin. 25% BC is HER2+ so that is a significant number/change in statistic. I have read that hormone suppression has made a huge difference too. I do believe some of these treatments have allowed us to live longer and disease free since the 50's.  Also remember that some people do survive (50%). Why not me?

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2011 05:47AM lago wrote: But Barbe what about us gals that have very fast growing AND hormone positive. Talk about not fitting into either category. HER2+ typically are Grade 3, very fast growing and hormone negative. When we are  hormone positive we usually aren't highly positive. (In my case 30%ER 5%PR). I feel there are no reliable stats for Herceptin treated HER2+ gals because they haven't been treating early stage with it for that long. It's still just a guessing game. Best to live my life and only start to worry if something doesn't feel quite right.

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2011 07:37AM lago wrote: Just an FYI. After menopause hair growth on legs, underarms and even pubic hair will not be as thick. As you age you will lose more in those areas. My underarm/leg hair growth had already started to slow a bit prior to this due to being perimenopausal. Granted it had now picked up a little bit since ending Herceptin but not quite as fast as it was before chemo.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2011 07:55PM - edited Nov 11, 2011 07:58PM by lago Chemopause can be perminent… actually in my case it most likely is and that's why I'm on Anastrozole instead of Tamoxifen. The closer you are in age to menopause when you go through chemopause the less likely it will come back. I was already peri. BTW I am currently 49+1. My onc also knew when my mom and sister went through menopause and did test my esterial levels for several months. I don't know if chemo would slow growth. I know that many of us on Herceptin experienced the slow growth. I'm still waiting for my nails to look normal. This woman in my building has slow growth hair but her nails look back to normal. She still has 2 herceptins to go (I finished early Sept.) I fear most of my finger nails will always be lifted granted some are worse than others. I also have those vertical ridges. My hair texture is still different but is getting a little better.

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2011 03:53PM lago wrote: Huskerkkc I was on taxotere/carboplatin. It is a very rare SE. And even if you do get it it's rare to get it as bad as I got it. Yes at one point my fingernail beds killed. Believe it or not, 11 weeks since my last chemo they are still a little sore. BUT there was only a few days that they hurt so bad that typing was an issue. I think you will still be able to play. I highly doubt you will get it as bad as I did. They started to hurt after my 3rd treatment. They hurt first, then lifted and got all icky. Also note that I didn't ice my fingers till it was too late. If you are that worried try bringing a couple of bags of frozen pees in an insulated bag to chemo and stick your fingers in them during taxol. BTW I'm not sure if this is a SE of taxol. Ask your onc.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 02:43PM lago wrote: Joan who said "10% of women on Taxotere don't get their hair back" That is a gross exaggeration. If it was that high it would be posted all over the place. It's more like 3% although still researching the number. Even on this site there are only a small number. I thought for sure I would be one of them since I had a receding hair line since I was in my mid 40's and using Minoxidil. I figured I rather be bald then be dead. Well guess what. Not only do I have all my hair back but a lot of the hair that receded came back. Still have some thinning on the left but very minor. Don't assume it will happen. It is very rare. BTW I did get the more rare SE from Taxotere. My nails are still not recovered (15 months out). Nail polish does a great job of hiding that so no biggy.

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 09:23AM lago wrote: Sonson my hair grew pretty fast although I was still on Herceptin so a bit slower at the time. I went topless at 13 weeks. I'm still wearing my hair uber short. No pony tail for me. Here is my hair transition linky mermaid_1010 I think there are several reasons why cold caps are not recommended. They are $$$ and a realy PITA to deal with. Can you imagine if everyone came in with dry ice in coolers with cold caps and how that would get in the way. It seems the chemo nurses are so busy and cold caps would just add more confusion if everyone was doing it. I would hope in the future cold caps and cold gloves/socks would be available to those that do the chemos (taxotere) that could cause permanent damage. (I had the bad nail lifting issue and my nails ever fully recovered). RainMaze I did 6 rounds of taxotere with Carboplatin and my hair came back fine. I read about this 3-6% right after my first TX. I assumed it would happen to me because I was already getting some receding before diagnosis. But it all came back, including a lot of the places it receded. Don't assume it will happen to you. Doing only 4 rounds makes it less likely from what I was told from my friend who has done a lot of research. SLKsMom I was on a different chemo but mine did thin during tx. Then fell out 5 weeks PFC. Came in great then thinned but I think that was from Anastrozole. I have been painting women's Minoxidil on them 1X a day and they are a little bit better and are not shedding anymore. BTW you ladies with hair pictures are looking awesome.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2014 01:22AM lago wrote: Finasteride is not covered by insurance. I would check with your onc if it's safe for you to use. It is not yet approved by FDA for women but it still can prescribed according to the source below. Also: "Side effects. Few adverse reactions have been noted in women receiving finasteride. Increased body hair, sweating and hot flashes, and headaches were reported during clinical studies of women receiving finasteride, but those effects were also noted in women not receiving the medication. (See here for a list of side effects reported in men.) Liver concerns. Finasteride should be used with caution by people with liver abnormalities because the drug is extensively metabolized in the organ." Bottom line. Finasteride has been used to treat female pattern hair loss and is reported to be effective for some women, but to date there is no good evidence from well-designed clinical trials to support its use for that purpose. Our advice: If you're a woman with thinning hair or significant hair loss, talk with your doctor about a referral to a specialist to look for underlying causes and approved treatments, such as minoxidil (Rogaine and generic). Finasteride probably plays little or no role in reversing hair loss in women with normal or low androgen levels. consumerreports.org/cro/2012/04/can-you-treat-women-s-hair-loss-with-a-drug-used-for-men/index.htm

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2014 12:53PM lago wrote: Yes Mikesgirl this can happen. Usually hairs are staggered growth. Once hair reaches it's life it falls off then starts growing a new one in it's place.  After chemo they aren't as staggered and it takes a while for them to stagger again. So it can really be noticeable with eyebrows and lashes when they fall out at about the same time. But eventually it staggers again.

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2012 11:40AM lago wrote: Soy is not bad. They really don't know what the deal is with soy. Processed soy I have read is bad but everything processed is crap so that's no surprise. I'm not saying change your diet to be high in soy but the amounts in most foods is small. Even your suppliments have some soy. I would discuss this with your onc. Same goes with parabens.  They haven't found any direct  links to breast cancer and parabens. They have low concentrations of them in breast cancer tumors. Also "Parabens have also displayed the ability to slightly mimic estrogen (a hormone known to play a role in the development of breast cancer" I think you really need to see how much you are really are exposed to. In most products its very minimal. Again I would discuss this with your onc. Personally I feel car exhaust and 2nd hand smoke are more important to avoid. (I live in a city so that is a bit more challenging than you think. I cross the street or pick up my pace just to not be downstream from a smoker).

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 08:11AM lago wrote: I actually got my scans before surgery because there was so much time. There seemed to be a spot on my liver but they all told me it was probably a cyst. When I met with my MO she said she wanted to scan my liver again after chemo. They did a more invasive scan and saw a few lesions again believing they were cysts. MO wanted to scan in a year. 1 year later (this past Feb) they now only see 2 spots with no change in size. Again she thinks they are cysts… but now my MO wants so scan in 6 months since I'm so far out from chemo. So just be prepared. Once they see something they will continue to scan. It can cause stress and is costly. I'm hoping that this next one is my last but I don't know. They say there is no increased risk in survival if they find mets early before you have symptoms. BTW I don't see an issue with you having scans. This is just my story.
Posts.Title: Scans After Surgery Heidi207 dogsandjogs

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 07:00PM lago wrote: tlundy I use generic (walgreen's) Minoxidil. I've been using it since 2004. It never altered my menstrual cycle back then. Since I now am in chemo-pause I don't have a cycle any way. The difference between men's and women's is women's is 2% and men's is 5%. It warns right on the package that if you use men's you could have an issue with growing some facial hair. I tried men's and that started to happen (although the hairs where blond in color). I switched to women's. I only use it once a day although it says twice. I would not use 5% unless you are directed to by your doctor ( preferably a dermatologist). My NP knows I'm using it again. I stopped using it when I was on chemo. But you should run it past your onc before trying.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2011 09:42AM lago wrote: Kate you look awesome. You have gorgeous hair. I wish I got my shine back like you. DoubleWhammy Yes there is a 1-3% chance (they think. Haven't been counting that long) of not getting your hair back on taxotere. It seems though that these women lose all their hair. It also seems the more tx you had the worse off you are. I had 6 tx. Mine came in fairly fast but I did have the male pattern baldness. I am taking 5 mg of Biotin daily and doing women's Minoxidil (generic Rogaine) once a day. Just remember with Minoxidil it can take 3-6 months for it to work. Other's have had luck with Nioxin products. That fact that you have some hair is a good sign. I know there have been others that have had slow growth. Also are you on any hormone therapy. Even chemo-pause will reduce the amount of estrogen in your body. Less estrogen can cause hair loss in some women. I would discuss this with your onc, gyno and/or dermatologist.

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 09:42PM lago wrote: Thanks Carrol, Marjie and Mr Margie. My "new" hair is different. Besides the extra gray and turning black the hair shafts are thinner but I have even more hair. It's very dull (I put stuff on it for shine) and sticks out straight. From what others say it does take 18 months to get close to what it was before. Yes I have eyebrows and lashes but both are thinner than when I was on chemo. Crazy. It takes time for all these drugs to get out of us. Some of us have herceptin. Some of us have AI or Tamox. Some of us have drugs from surgery. Drugs to combat chemo effects. All of this takes time to get out of your system. Any/all of these can effect your hair & nails. Surgery can effect hair growth too.

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 09:32PM lago wrote: slcst12 we are pretty sure my chemopause is permanent. I was 49 on chemo. Turn 50 three weeks after chemo ended. I was already peri. Believe it or not my hot flashes have stopped for the most part except when I eat my chili. Guess hot banana peppers is my trigger… or at least I think I had a hot flash last night. You should talk to your onc about this. There is a chance at your age that  your cycle could come back. From what I read it could be a year or 2. The closer you are to menopausal age the more likely it will be permanent. Under 40 I think you have a good chance yours will be back. My hot flashes (night only when I had them) where really not too bad. I never really got sweaty. Just warm. I would talk to your onc about this too. They have a drug for that too if it's really out of control. Also I found cotton scarves to be a lot cooler than other fabrics.

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2011 08:10AM - edited Sep 24, 2011 08:21AM by lago survivor11 I too had thick hair before chemo. I feel my hair shafts were a little thinner than before but my hair is thicker (even my hair dresser said my hair is thicker ). I'm keeping it short for now but  I do feel in time the old hair will come back. It's just going to take a while. fluffqueen01 I have read some folks complaining that Herceptin will slow hair growth. I just had my last Herceptin 2.5 weeks ago. I sure hope my hair doesn't grow any faster. I feel I'm getting it cut every 4 weeks now as it is. Now my neighbor (we have all the same doctors and treatments except she got rads) finds her hair is growing very slowly. Could be from Herceptin. She is also over 10 years older than me so that could be it too. She really wants to stop wearing her wig and have hair like mine. I explain that there are many women on that their hair just comes in slower… but it does come back. I think my challenges are my nails(toes & fingers), eyebrows and eyelashes. I have a feeling that could take 2 years and in the case of my toe nails some will always be messed up. Not a big deal. I'm not a foot model.

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 08:21PM - edited Feb 26, 2012 08:22PM by lago CaitlinB When I went to chemo training my NP told me people with hair like mine usually have a hard time with hair loss. I had beautiful, thick, silky bob just above my shoulders. I looked at her and said I was more worried about my eyebrows. I was so concerned that I bought product to fill in my eyebrows before my initial surgery. I did get the wig (my avatar is me in the wig after my 4th tx). I wore it 2x. It was hot, uncomfortable and too big. I wore scarves the rest of the time (and big earrings). One of the pictures here I'm wearing my scarf. I was 1 month PFC: linky   If there is a looks good feel better program near you I recommend going. They will give you make-up tips. It really is all about your face not your hair. (If not all the info is one the site). If you decide to get a wig and you have really thick hair like me I either recommend really shaving your hair down or waiting till it falls out so it won't be too big. Wigs are designed assuming people have some hair so they tend to run big.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 10:47AM - edited Feb 8, 2013 10:48AM by lago InTheWind I would do it again! My onc gave me stats for my age and diagnosis that said that out of 100 women who were my age with my diagnosis that only did the surgery… only 40 of them were alive and cancer free 10 years later. If I did the chemo and in my case hormone therapy my chance of being alive and cancer free went up to 86%. There is no known cure but the chances of being cured are high if you treat it now. Once  you reach stage IV there is no cure. They just manage the disease with treatment (meaning off and on chemo for the rest of your life which could be months or 20 years). If you are on chemo the rest of your life you are not without side effects. So now is your best shot of a cure. I would give up a year of my life (actually more when you include reconstruction) again to have this great opportunity to cancer free and possibly cured. My hair is back and looks great. Also ask your oncologist to explain the risks of ILC. It's a sneaky one and I do believe it might have a higher risk of metastisis… but please check with your onc on that. I had a bit 6.5cm tumor of IDC/DCIS in the left and a small amount of LCIS on the right. Had to get the MX but once the LCIS was found a BMX was recommended. I did have TEs places at BMX (start of reconstruction) PM me if you what to chat more.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2014 04:36PM lago wrote: noonrider your hair texture and thickness will return to it's former self most likely after 12-18 months. As far as the AI remember you can always try it then if you have SE quit. You're hair will grow back if it falls out on the AI just like it grew back on Chemo. If you are that worried you can always try Minoxidil. That's what I use because it started to recede before chemo due to peri menopause. The generic isn't all that expensive either. But once the cancer has become metastatic you will be battling that the rest of your life… and it most likely will not be a normal life span. I started this battle at age 49. I've had a few issues with the AIs and I'm on my 2nd one. Most of the SE have gone away on this one. Don't assume the worst. I though I was going to get every SE on chemo and have the worst nausea because I too don't play well with meds. I never took anything for nausea, never had it.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2014 06:55PM lago wrote: noonrider Rads and BMX only take care of local cancer cells. Chemo and Hormone therapy do the entire system and can target any cells that might have gone into your system that might have broken away from the tumor (or escaped through the lymph nodes if you had involvement). Also you still have some breast tissue. We have about a 2-3% chance of developing a new breast cancer from the tissue that is left. It happened to a friend of mine. She had BMX, Chemo etc. Hormone therapy can prevent that.

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2014 08:42AM lago wrote: noonrider you need to ask your onc to get the specifics for you. It's a combination of things including tumor size, grade, age, family history. My MO says even though I don't have nodes I'm high risk for recurrence if I don't do the hormone therapy because of the size of my tumor. Lymph nodes are the typical way the cancer cells can escape but they don't know everything about this disease. There are women that do get mets but never had any node involvement (according to our current methods of testing). Highest risk for recurrence is in the first 2 years. After that your risk drops and continues to drop as you get further out. I have read that low grade can recur years later more often than high grade but I don't know how big the study was.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 06:24PM lago wrote: Insurance in the US depends on the plan. There is a good chance if your husband to be works for a large company that there is no lifetime cap or maximum coverage. There probably is some kind of deductible (amount you must pay before you are covered each year). There is also could be a maximum out-of-pocket (per year)… this means once you have reached that maximum you will have no more out-of-pocket for the year. There probably is a preferred provider coverage. This means if you see a physician/ treatment center that is a preferred provider they will cover more. For instance the plan I'm on covers 80% of the cost once my deductible is met of a preferred provider. If it's out of network the only cover 60% of what they deem a customary charge for the procedure (usually lower than what they would allow for in-network). So it is in your best interest to go with a preferred provider. There should be some kind of booklet or online information that will explain all of this as well as define some of the terms I'm using. I would ask your husband to be to talk with the HR department about getting a copy. They should be able to provide this.
Posts.Title: health insurance questions kebab epgnyc

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2012 01:51AM lago wrote: Here are a couple of links to explain the difference between HMO and PPO. The one main difference is with an HMO your primary care physician (PCP) will have to give you are referral to a specialist. In a PPO you do not need to get a referral. This doesn't mean they tell you which specialist you can see. It's like getting a note from mom… allowing you to see a specialist. linky linky as far as Kaiser Permanente…like all insurances depending on the state they work a little differently in terms of what they cover and how much. If your head is spinning don't be discouraged. It is confusing. I used to do dental claims in a dentist office years ago. That's part of the reason I have some understanding of this bullsh*t process we have in the US called health "insurance".

Posts.Content: May 12, 2012 11:27AM lago wrote: I saw my breast surgeon first. Once we decided on BMX with reconstruction I met with 2 plastic surgeons. 2 weeks after my surgery I met with the medical oncologist and then radiation oncologist (got a pass on rads). Depending on the type of initial surgery and diagnosis after surgery will dictate what course of action and who you see next. My oncologist knew about my situation before surgery (Have a relative that works at the treatment center and discussed my biopsy results with her). She (my onc) didn't want to see me before surgery nor did she suggest chemo first. I asked my BS about chemo first and he, at that time didn't recommend it in my case. Granted  it seems now more people with larger and/or aggressive tumors are getting it first especially if they are node positive. Both the physical and MRI indicated I was probably node negative although my PS did worry about micromets. Chemo before or after… no increase in survival benefits. The good thing about doing it first is you can see if it's working. Good thing about doing it after surgery is they know for sure what is in there. I might have never know my nodes were clear if I did chemo first. If I had micromets good chance chemo would have taken care of it. They might have recommended radiation in that case since I was in a gray area. I'm glad I got out of rads. I did the BRCA testing before surgery as well. Ended up I needed to do the double anyway but I didn't know that because I was waiting for the MRI results. I do recommend BRCA testing before surgery. This could change your mind as to what kind of surgery you want to do if you test positive. ---------------------------------- Bottom line get 2nd or even 3rd opinions but try to go to a breast surgeon/breast center. They will be more current on breast cancer treatment and know what's best for you in your case. If you are node negative and HER2- there's a chance won't get chemo but if you are HER2+ and/or hormone negative you probably will. They will do what's called an oncotype test after they remove the tumor if you are node negative, HER2- and ER/PR+. There is more than one way to treat this disease and they are all good approaches if you are being treated by people who know what they are doing. Hope that makes sense.

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 01:46PM lago wrote: CYnthia you should ask for a copy of your path report. It's your right. The biopsy is not always 100% accurate. Granted if it says you have cancer you do but the biopsy only samples small areas. The tumor can be a combination so you won't have the complete info till after the surgery to remove the tumor. Your surgeon should have a copy of the path report. Make sure it's sent to him. I highly recommend you get more than one opinion. In most cases cancer doesn't grow that fast so you have some time. I did have a very large fast growing tumor (not all that unusual for those of us that are pre or perim menopausal). It was grade 3 and HER2+ It was 6 weeks after my biopsy that I finally had surgery… 2 months post mammogram/Ultra sound. I've been NED (no evidence of disease) for 2 years 2 months. I'm doing great. This is the scaries time. The women here are wonderful and supportive. Ask questions but remember we are not doctors with medical degrees. Use this site to get information to ask your docotr but don't assume it's accurate. You have a specific medical/family history so things might be different for you. After all we are just a bunch of strangers here. I'll keep checking in. Also you can PM (Private message) people by clicking on their name. On that page you will see link to send a private message

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2010 08:10AM lago wrote: My BS said that even removing the breast can cause lymphoma. I had sentinel on the left (4 nodes). Although the risk is lower with just a sentinel I find the hospital is very diligent about not sticking me or blood pressure on that arm. On the right I had 10 nodes removed. All clear. The reason the BS did this is to make sure there was no micro-invasion. My tumor was large, aggressive grade3/HER2+. The chances of a micro invasion was like 80%. Having this knowledge allowed for proper staging and treatment. Had they not done this I bet I would have had to go through at least 8 rounds of chemo instead of 6and maybe rads too. I think I rather lose 10 nodes then have more chemo and rads. Chemo/rads have more serious SE.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 07:41PM - edited Jan 19, 2013 07:43PM by lago I too had the big C issue. Metamucil worked for me (3X a day as directed till things were moving normally). I also ate dried apricots and took Nutraflora (as directed 1X a day) in my water. I still do the Nutraflora because I have IBS and constipation can be an issue. This all helped soften the stool so it was much easier to pass. Meticmucil also isn't bloating. I would start taking it the night of chemo then as mentioned earlier stop when things were back to nomal (about 4-5 days). Milk of Magnesia didn't work for me but hopefully it will work for you

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2010 07:23AM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:54AM by lago Bec You have been through quite a bit. I do understand the aggressiveness  of you tx. I too am triple positive. I assume you are grade 3 too. I am stage IIB only because I have no lymph node involvement therefore I do not have as many treatments as you and didn't need radiation. (Note I was in a very gray area for rads but my rads oncologist didn't recommend it based on all the other treatment I had.) The reason for being so aggressive is your HER2+ status. HER2+ is very aggressive and has a tendency to spread to other parts of the body. When treated you have a much, much, much better prognosis of it not spreading. Your oncologist should be giving you the statistics on this. Although your tumor is DCIS I believe you are being treated for IDC because it has spread to the nodes. I would ask your oncologist about that too. I think you need more information from you oncologist before you decide to stop treatment. I know how tired you must be going through all this. I can only image since I just started chemo and my treatment isn't quite as long. Just remember if you do decide to continue the end of the road is a lot closer than you think.6 more infusions… only 3.5 months maybe? You've come so far.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 03:20AM - edited Feb 6, 2012 03:21AM by lago My BS syas I'm NED (No evidence of disease). I think this is the best language to use. As far as HER2+ I know my much older post menopausal neighbor (stage III) got the exact same treatment as I did. She too was HER2+. Staging is a guide to treatment but there are other factors like your age, HER2 & hormonal status, menopausal status that play a big part in your treatment. HER2+, triple negative, family history, BRCA+ and younger agealmost always will be treated more agressively than those that are not.

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 08:03AM lago wrote: whatRstatsanyway pretty much covered it. I just finished my 6th THC on Tuesday. I am unfortunately unemployed but I would say the first 3 tx I wouldn't have missed a day if I was working. After the 4th it would have been a bit more challenging but still doable. I would get tired at about 4-5pm days 2-4. After 5pm on those days I would crash on the couch. I never did get any nausea but even if you do there are drugs to handle that. I also found the more active I was the better I handled treatment… working might actually be a benefit for you. I too did the nuelasta. I did take Aleve to combat the aches for a day. I so far have not been sick and my white counts have been normal. I even eat sushi! Bottom line is you won't know till your 1st tx. Once you have your first round though you will find most SE are managed. The came the same day each time for me. You may have to take a few days off but I'm guessing you will be able to work most of your schedule. I'm 49. Hang in there. You'll be surprised how fast it goes by. BTW it's hard to know what you will miss regarding surgery without know what kind of surgery you will have.

According to what I have read my risk factors where I'm female, white, no kids and dense breast tissue. I hardly ever drank, not over weight, exercise, eat healthy, almost never ill, etc.

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2012 11:57PM lago wrote: 5kidsMom I has surgery before chemo. Standard care it to remove at least level I nodes (not sentinel) on tumors bigger than 5cm because the probability is at least 80% that there will be some mets in the nodes. My BS was worried I would have micromets. In your case (just my guess, I don't really know) the fact that its in your intramammory node might give a strong indication that  you could have micromets in your nodes. If you did the chemo might have killed it but since you aren't removing the axillary nodes they want to do radiation instead. The risk of LE is a little lower with just rads versus removing lots of nodes. Be sure they measure your arm before rads just in case of LE. You need a baseline. I never got one so we really don't know how much my LE arm swelled. Hope that makes sense.

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2012 02:31PM lago wrote: Leanna your follow up should include physical exam and probably MRI. NCI standard is not MRI but a friend of mine had the same issue. Because of dense tissue her cancer was found by the MRI. Both she and another friend were going to an NCI approved center and wasn't doing MRIs. Her friend went to my onc (different treatment center not NCI approved) to get a second opinion. My onc agreed that she should be getting MRIs but felt it was silly for her to have to change treatment centers just so she could get an MRI. She (my onc) actually wrote a letter to her onc stating this. (My onc is pretty well respected in the industry). Now my friend and her friend both get MRIs as well as mammo on their remaining breast  (tests 6 months apart). So maybe you need to get a 2nd opinion at a non NCI approved center.

I  also had 1 more chemo in Janurary and was doing physical therapy although that is done. Started this insurance in January and have already met the deductable. No Rads though. HIPPA/No gap only applies if you are going from one group plan to another. If you are trying to get individual insurance gap or no gap they can refuse you and/or your pre-existing condition. This will change in 2014 when (and if) Obama care is in place.

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2011 07:39PM lago wrote: My mammo/US came back as bi rads 4. I then took all my images to another places (current treatment center). They confirmed I needed a biopsy. I kinda knew I was screwed when the BS was looking at the images and kept saying "I'm not a radiologist. I really need a radiologist to look at these." Then he started to talk a little later about how breast cancer is very treatable. At the biopsy I asked the radiologist what was going on before he started. He came right out and said "We are doing this biopsy not to see if you have breast cancer but to prove our diagnosis of breast cancer. If the biopsy doesn't prove it then we will do a more invasive procedure to prove it" To be honest it was no big shock but hard to hear. I had bloody discharge and I could feel this large hard area. Not a lump but a hard area. I knew this was no papaloma. I was not in a high risk group. I hope they are wrong about you and it's benign. There is always that possibility till then tell you otherwise.

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 08:35PM lago wrote: Texas I highly recommend going to the LE specialist at least once to get a good fitting. It's worth the 50 mile trip. You might not have a good fit. I 1st got my sleeves/gloves as a preventive to wear during flying. My BS sent me to a place in the hospital. Few months later I ended up with LE. If find out that my sleeves are too short AND my glove fingers are too short too. The glove isn't such a bit deal because my fingers don't swell but the sleeve was. I got them to exchange but I will never go back.They also insisted I get the silicon which irritated me. I don't need the silicon. Silicon is good if you have larger arms to prevent rolling. I have very thin arms even with LE. An LE PE will take measurements and let you know what you should purchase… you may need something custom. My LE MD says he never orders gloves off the shelf for anyone. They never fit right.

First of all yes we should know our bodies but they do change and that's a normal thing. Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2012 05:05AM lago wrote: 5kidsMom things happen so fast at the beginning for all of us. I wish I knew more too. Don't be concerned that you didn't get "standard care". Just because it's standard doesn't mean it's right for you. Standard care for premenopausal women that are  hormone positive get tamoxifen. My onc put me on Anastrozole because she felt my cycles at my age (and family history) would not come back. Not standard care but I'm fine with that. My onc first diagnosed me with LE but didn't send me to a PT. When it continued to get worse I then contacted my PS. He sent me to a specialist who then sent me toa PT. My onc is great but this was the one time she didn't seem too concerned so I just moved on to the next MD. My PCP is also great. I'm sure your PCP will send you to a PT at least for an evaluation.

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 07:50AM lago wrote: Just a note about the http://www.lifemath.net/cancer/ site The copyright for the application is 2007-2008. The stats are the average of patients from 1987-2006. There have been new developments in that time. Especially if you are HER2+ I fear these stats give a worse prognosis than actually true now that herceptin with chemo is now standard treatment for HER2+ This is what's under the frequently asked questions: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Do the calculators take into account treatment with drug _______? The treatment calculators take into account only those specific drugs (or analogues) listed in the treatment selection menu. The Outcome calculators are based on observed outcomes for cancer patients from 1987-2006. Thus they do include data for any treatments used during this time period. However, the calculator may not reflect the full impact of treatments developed later in that time period, or not widely used until later in that period. Do the calculators take into account differing surgical treatments? The calculators are based on observed outcomes for cancer patients from 1987-2006. Thus they are based on data including all surgical treatments used during this time period, and the relative frequency of a given surgical procedure for a given tumor type.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2011 09:16AM lago wrote: Sheila, my BS pretty much thought I would be a stage IIIA because he really thought there would be a micro-invasion in my node(s) and of course my tumor size (and grade). I ended up a stage IIB because my nodes were clear. I'm sure if my nodes where not clear I would be getting radiation. I was in a grey area and my rad onc felt the risk out-weighed the benefit considering all the other aggressive treatment. So as you can see they must draw lines but sometimes there isn't a huge difference. Bottom line is we really need to look at staging as a guide for being treated and not how likely we are to recur.
